sen.j: 太政官厨家（だいじょうかんちゅうけ）は、本来は太政官に付属する厨房を指すが、古代においてはこれを管理する官司を指した。
sen.e: The original meaning of the term Daijokan chuke was the kitchen of Daijokan (the Great Council of State), but in the ancient times, it referred to government officials who administered the kitchen of Daijokan.

The Daijokan chuke essentially indicated the kitchen that belonged to the Daijokan (Grand Council of State), but in ancient times the term referred to the government officials who administered the Daijokan kitchen.
sen.cmt: fixed to read more naturally
sen.e: The Daijokan chuke essentially indicated the kitchen that belonged to the Daijokan (Grand Council of State), but in ancient times the term referred to the government officials who administered the Daijokan kitchen.
sen.cmt: 修正なし

sen.j: 太政官における会議や行事の際に出される食事の準備やそのために必要な用具・雑貨などの調達などを本来の職務としていた。
sen.e: Their principal jobs were preparing food for conferences and events of Daijokan as well as procuring necessary tools and miscellaneous goods.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外処理
sen.e: The primary duties of the Daijokan chuke were to provide any equipment or novelties needed in order to prepare food served at conferences and events in the Daijokan.
sen.cmt: Changed sentence order and fixed grammar to read more naturally
sen.e: The primary duties of the Daijokan chuke were to provide any equipment or novelties needed in order to prepare food served at conferences and events in the Daijokan.
sen.cmt: 修正なし

sen.j: 同時にその食料や費用に充てる公田（乗田）地子の管理や弁官以下の太政官官人や雑用を行う召使までの禄米・時服などの給与の支払なども行った。
sen.e: At the same time, they were in charge of the administration of jishi (land tax) of koden (joden) (field administered directly by a ruler) which was allotted to such food or expenses as well as the provision of rokumai (rice allowance) and jifuku (seasonal clothes) to the officials of Dijokan, including benkan (officials of Daijokan) and other servants engaged in odd jobs.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外処理
sen.e: Concurrently, other duties included the administration of jishi (land rent paid by farmers) on koden (or joden) (field administered directly by a ruler) that were set aside to cover their food and expenses, They also handled payments of wages in rice and jifuku (seasonal clothing) for everyone from Daijokan officials under the Benkan (division of the Daijokan responsible for controlling central and provincial governmental offices) to servants who did menial labor.
sen.cmt: Deleted "rokumai"and left it as "wages in rice" because there is no wikipedia article on it;
sen.e: Concurrently, other duties included the administration of jishi (land rent paid by farmers) on koden (or joden) (field administered directly by a ruler) that were set aside to cover their food and expenses, they also handled payments of wages in rice and jifuku (seasonal clothing) for everyone from Daijokan officials under the Benkan (division of the Daijokan responsible for controlling central and provincial governmental offices) to servants who did menial labor.
sen.cmt: 表記を変えました。

sen.j: 延喜式によれば、責任者である別当（べっとう）は少納言・弁官・外記・史_(律令制)からそれぞれ1名が兼務した。
sen.e: According to "the Engishiki" (an ancient book for codes and procedures on national rites and prayers), each one person of shonagon (Lesser Council of State), benkan Controller), geki (Secretary of the Grand Council of State) and shi (Riysuryo system) concurrently assumed the position of betto (responsible person) and each one shisho (a person doing miscellaneous duties about documents) of shonagonkyoku (Lesser Councilors' Office) and benkankyoku (Controllers' Office) were appointed to azukari (a deputy).
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外処理
sen.e: According to the "Engishiki" (set of ancient Japanese governmental regulations), one officer at a time from the Shonagon (lesser councilor of state), Benkan (oversight department), Geki (Secretary of the Grand Council of State) and Shi (Officials in charge of records) each held the position of Betto as the person in charge concurrently with their normal position. Following this example, officers were assigned one at a time as an azukari (deputy) of Shisho (official in charge of miscellaneous documents) at the Shonagon and Benkan bureaus.
sen.cmt: The original wiki article is written as one sentence combined with the one below. I changed the Japanese to match the article and added the 「、」in red. The sentence is too long to keep as one in English, however;
sen.e: According to the Engishiki (codes and procedures on national rites and prayers), one officer at a time from the Shonagon (lesser councilor of state), Benkan (oversight department), Geki (Secretary of the Grand Council of State) and Shi (Officials in charge of records) each held the position of Betto as the person in charge concurrently with their normal position.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処。

sen.j: これに続く預（あずかり）は少納言局・弁官局の史生より各1名ずつが充てられた。
sen.cmt: 修正なし
sen.e: Following this example, officers were assigned one at a time as an azukari (deputy) of Shisho (official in charge of miscellaneous documents) at the Shonagon and Benkan bureaus.

sen.j: 毎年2月に太政官が行う列見の儀式までの1年間ずつの交替制であった。
sen.e: Their term was one year until Rekken no gishiki held by Daijokan in February each year.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外処理 列見の儀式→読み、定訳不明
sen.e: The duty was part of a shift system with a term of one year each, ending every year in February at the Rekken Ceremony (an annual ritual during the Heian and Nara Periods in which officers were evaluated for promotions).
sen.cmt: 列見 information found at <http://www.weblio.jp/content/%E5%88%97%E8%A6%8B>
sen.e: The duty was part of a shift system with a term of one year each, ending every year in February at the Rekken Ceremony (an annual ritual during the Heian and Nara Periods in which officers were evaluated for promotions).

sen.j: 公田の地子を舂米・軽貨の形で送られて太政官厨家に納められた他、諸国から集められた例進納物もここに納められた。
sen.e: Jishi of koden was delivered to Daijokan chuke in the form of shomai (rice made by pounding it in a mortar) or keika and other reishinnomotsu from various provinces was also delivered there.
sen.cmt: 軽貨→読み、定訳不明 例進納物→読み、定訳不明
sen.e: Koden Jishi (land taxes) were delivered to the Daijokan chuke in the form of shomai (rice that has been pounded in a mortar) and keika along with reishinnomotsu from various provinces.
sen.cmt: I had no luck in finding either 「軽貨」 or 「例進納物」 so I left them as is; fixed other grammar
sen.e: Koden Jishi (land taxes) were delivered to the Daijokan chuke in the form of shomai (rice that has been pounded in a mortar) and keika (軽貨) along with reishinnomotsu (例進納物) from various provinces.
sen.cmt: 読み・意味が確認できなかった漢字を補足しました。

sen.j: だが、後に班田制の崩壊と位田などの増加、国司による地子の正税などへの転用によって本来は班田の余剰田であった乗田及びその地子も減少するようになった。
sen.e: However, due to the collapse of handensei (state controlled land allotment system), the increase of iden (fields given according to the court rank) and the conversion of jishi to shozei (rice tax of provincial office) by provincial governors, the number of joden, which was basically the extra fields of handen (the allotted fields), as well as its jishi gradually decreased later.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外処理
sen.e: Later on, however, due to the collapse of the handensei (state controlled land allotment system), the increase of iden (fields alotted according to court rank) and Kokushi (provincial governors) converting jishi to shozei (rice taxed by provincial offices), the number of joden, which were essentially the extra fields of handen (alloted fields), were gradually decreased along with their jishi.
sen.cmt: added "Kokushi" for "provincial governors" since there is a wikipedia article on them; fixed grammar mistakes and made sentence read more naturally
sen.e: Later on, however, due to the collapse of the handensei (state controlled land allotment system), the increase of iden (fields allotted according to court rank) and Kokushi (provincial governors) converting jishi to shozei (rice taxed by provincial offices), the number of joden, which were essentially the extra fields of handen (allotted fields), were gradually decreased along with their jishi.

sen.j: 便補保と呼ばれる一種の荘園が設置されてそれが乗田の代わりとされた。
sen.e: Under such situation, ben no ho, a kind of shoen (manor), was established in place of joden.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外処理
sen.e: As a result, a variety of Shoen (manor) called a "ben no ho" was established in place of the joden.
sen.cmt: added quotation marks are "Ben no ho" since the characters are written in read on the original wikipedia article; fixed grammar to read more naturally
sen.e: As a result, a variety of Shoen (manor) called a Ben no ho was established in place of the joden.

sen.j: また、本来太政官厨家は少納言局と弁官局が共同で管理することになっていたが、蔵人所の設置で少納言及び少納言局の職掌が形骸化すると、専ら弁官局が管理するようになった。
sen.e: Although Daijokan chuke was originally supposed to be administered jointly by shonagonkyoku and benkankyoku, it came to be administered solely by benkankyoku after the jobs of shonagon and shonagonkyoku became a mere façade due to the establishment of kurododokoro (Board of Archivists).
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外処理
sen.e: Athough it was originally intended for the Daijokan chuke to be administered jointly by the Shonagon and Benkan bureaus, it ended up being solely administered by the Benkan bureau once the Shonagon and Shonagon bureau lost their substance due to the establishment of the Kurododokoro (Board of Archivists).
sen.cmt: changed translation of "-kyoku" to "Bureau" of Shonagon and Benkan; capitalized "Shonagon," "Benkan" and "Kurododokoro";
sen.e: Although it was originally intended for the Daijokan chuke to be administered jointly by the Shonagon and Benkan bureaus, it ended up being solely administered by the Benkan bureau once the Shonagon and Shonagon bureau lost their substance due to the establishment of the Kurododokoro (Board of Archivists).
sen.cmt: スペル修正しました。

sen.j: 更に残された乗田や便補保も代々官務（左大史）を務めた小槻氏の事実上の所領となっていった。
sen.e: Further, remaining joden and ben no ho virtually became the territory of Ozuka clan which successively served as kanmu (inherited official position) (sadaishi (senior recorder of the left)).
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外処理
sen.e: In addition, remaining joden and "ben no ho" effectively became territory of the Ozuka clan who passed their service as Kanmu (also known as Sadaishi which was the senior recorder of the left) from one generation to the next.
sen.cmt: eliminated "(inherited official position)" as it was not needed; eliminated double parenthesis and turned "Sadaishi" into a description of Kanmu; fixed grammar to read more naturally
sen.e: In addition, remaining joden and Ben no ho effectively became territory of the Ozuki clan who passed their service as Kanmu (also known as Sadaishi which was the senior recorder of the left) from one generation to the next.
